{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3534902,"name":"Jacob","username":"_Jacob","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_jacob/{size}/211203_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T01:03:06.817Z","cooked":"

Hello,
I am trying to figure out what gains we should use for our robot and I need some help. I did some research and found this calculator, which output the following:
kG = 0.15
kV = 11.65

I also found a CD post that said to do this:

kG+kS = Voltage just barely BELOW upward crawl
kG-kS = Voltage just barely ABOVE downward crawl

Using these equations, I tested to find their values by outputting motor voltage to the SmartDashboard.
Voltage just before elev goes up: 0.81V
Voltage just before elev goes dn: 0.34V
and calculated kS and kG as follows:
kS = 0.235
kG = 0.575

When I use these three values
kS = 0.235
kG = 0.575
kV = 11.65

the elevator works, but when it reaches it’s setpoint the motor lets out the stall noise. It doesn’t move (which means the FeedForward is working), but I can tell it’s not right. We are using two Kraken x60 motors attached to a gearbox to turn the elevator.

My first question is this: what could be a reason as to why the calculator result and recommended result so different?
Second question: How should I fix the stalling?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T01:03:06.817Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":130,"reads":186,"readers_count":185,"score":697.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"Jacob","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/linear","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":27},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/stuck-tuning-vertical-elevator-feedforward-pid/492268/6","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Stuck tuning vertical elevator (feedforward/PID)","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63329,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3534915,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T01:10:08.458Z","cooked":"

I’d argue stalling the motor to hold the elevator stationary is the expected behavior. Indeed, if you were to turn off the motor, your kg-ks result implies it would sink down.

The motor needs to be exerting torque to hold the elevator in place.

Since you’re not attempting to move the elevator, this implies you should be running the motor at a small voltage which stalls it out against the force of gravity acting on the elevator.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T03:52:06.889Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":159,"readers_count":158,"score":51.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534922,"name":null,"username":"anon74528069","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/46a35a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T01:14:12.169Z","cooked":"

we had the same issue, but when we re-did it this is how we did :

  1. tune the Kg so that it puts out a tiny voltage but DOES NOT lift
  2. add some ks, to make it barely lift
  3. add kv until it gets very close to your setpoint/goal

and add a pid if needed. this worked for us and it stopped stalling when we had a lower kg and a higher P in our pid.

(for reference we are using falcons)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T01:15:06.529Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":151,"readers_count":150,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64292,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_suspended":true,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535186,"name":"icemannie","username":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T09:50:35.355Z","cooked":"

What distance and velocity units are you using for your elevator?
Kv units are volts per whatever distance / velocity units you scaled your motor / encoder to.
You can get a good starting estimate from dividing 12 (battery voltage} by the maximum velocity it can achieve.
11.95 is pretty much battery volts so it says your maximum velocity is 1 inch per second or meter per second or whatever units you chose.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T09:50:35.355Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":37.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535247,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T14:23:19.481Z","cooked":"
_Jacob:

My first question is this: what could be a reason as to why the calculator result and recommended result so different?

Because a correctly tuned kG should not result in elevator movement. It is tuned correctly when it is equally easy to move the elevator up and down. If this system is a cascade elevator, you will need to correctly account for the cascade upduction when calculating kG, which can result in errors.

icemannie:

You can get a good starting estimate from dividing 12 (battery voltage} by the maximum velocity it can achieve

(Free voltage - free current / effective armature resistance) / free speed gives you a more accurate result by accounting for friction. While just knowing the back-emf constant directly would be better, FRC vendors can’t properly document their motors unlike every other motor manufacturer.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T14:23:19.481Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":126,"readers_count":125,"score":40.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535388,"name":"Jacob","username":"_Jacob","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/_jacob/{size}/211203_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T16:39:20.572Z","cooked":"
icemannie:

What distance and velocity units are you using for your elevator?

This is the unit output by the calculator.

Alex_Y:

If this system is a cascade elevator, you will need to correctly account for the cascade upduction when calculating kG, which can result in errors.

We are using a 3 step cascade elevator. The only way I have found to calculate kG is from the post I linked originally, is there some other way I should? Also, I’m not familiar with what upduction is and I can’t seem to find a definition anywhere. Would you be able to explain a little more what you mean and how to find this?

Here is a video of the elevator. You can hear the stall noise in it and see that it stays in place. It moves a little fast going down and not quite fast enough up, but I think (hope?) that fixing the gains and tuning PID will fix that.
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Kw2c563pjHrMwYBPOX0vqrcOj_sZgjom/view?usp=drivesdk

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T16:44:43.258Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":104,"readers_count":103,"score":45.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"Jacob","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Kw2c563pjHrMwYBPOX0vqrcOj_sZgjom/view?usp=drivesdk","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IMG_7771.MOV - Google Drive","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63329,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535412,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T17:12:01.626Z","cooked":"
_Jacob:

Also, I’m not familiar with what upduction is and I can’t seem to find a definition anywhere.

Gear reduction but the thing goes faster. Upduction is not a standardized term, but a 1:3 upduction has a much more clear meaning than 1:3 reduction.

You can analytically calculate all feedforwards, and in fact, it is the first thing I would reccomend trying, and is often accurate enough. kG is simply just adding the effective weight as a torque to the motor. For a cascade, add the weight of the first stage, 4x the weight of the 2nd stage, 9x the weight of the 3rd stage… as a torque on the motor. Torque outputted by a motor is the torque constant times the phase current, the former of which can be found in the CTRE motor testing data and the latter you can control with FOC, or calculate using (V* thetadot)/ra where the voltage is just a voltage to add for gravity compensation, ra is caluclated by dividing stall current by stall torque, and thetadot is read from the encoder.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T17:12:01.626Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":21.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535417,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T17:15:41.395Z","cooked":"
Alex_Y:

You can analytically calculate all feedforwards

Ks is a bit tricky…

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T17:15:41.395Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":82,"readers_count":81,"score":31.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535424,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T17:19:34.365Z","cooked":"
_Jacob:

Second question: How should I fix the stalling?

“Stalling” is what you should have here, there is voltage applied but no movement. That is why the motors will make the stall noise. If you plot stator current via api or using tuner x that will indicate if you have an actual issue. An output voltage of 0.8ish volts seems reasonable.

Through testing, the maximum velocity of the elevator motor was about 24 rotations per second, so I think that’s about 2.2m/s. I found this by putting the maximum value of TalonFX#getVelocity() to the SmartDashboard.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T19:52:33.630Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":60,"readers_count":59,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492527,"topic_slug":"feedforward-gains","display_username":"Jacob","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28240,"username":"icemannie","name":"icemannie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/bc79bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63329,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/feedforward-gains/492527/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535671,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T20:06:18.434Z","cooked":"
_Jacob:

Is there a way to silence the stall noise then?

Increase the gear ratio until the effort to hold position falls below the firmware threshold.

Starting estimate for kv is battery voltage divided by max velocity which is about 5.5.
That’s the second post that had a calculator kv out by a factor of 2 Elevator PID Tuning Issues with Gravity - Technical / Programming - Chief Delphi
You can observe the voltage to the motor using a Smart Dashboard.putNumber statement in elevator periodic

motor,getAppliedOutput()*RobotController.getBatteryVoltage()
